1. One of these events in 1973 dubbed the "Battle of Versailles" pitted Frenchmen against Americans like Bill Blass. Linda Evangelista and Christy Turlington unusually locked arms to George Michael's "Freedom! '90" at one of these events in 1991 that preceded the "waif" era. At these events, which may be organized by people like Oscar de la Renta, people in the highly-sought "frow" (rhymes with "mow") watch as someone who created their (*) concept leads a finale. One of these events hosted by Alexander McQueen included a hologram of Kate Moss. The "Big Four" are week-long collections of these events which show off haute couture ("oht coo-tyur") collections in cities like New York and Milan. For 10 points, name these events in which models catwalk a runway.
ANSWER: fashion shows [or fashion events; accept a fashion week; accept a runway show; prompt on trade shows or trade fairs or trade exhibitions or trade expositions; prompt on shows; prompt on catwalks] (The second line is the Versace Fall 1991 RTW Runway Show.)

The assassination of Donaldo Colosio after the passage of this agreement hurt the presidency of Carlos Salinas de Gortari. A crisis after this agreement's enactment led to the Debt Disclosure Act during Ernesto Zedillo's presidency. This agreement triggered the (*) Zapatista Uprising in Chiapas. The peso crisis occurred shortly after this agreement, despite the economic opportunities it was promised to create. Following this agreement, maquiladoras ("mah-KEE-lah-DOR-ahz") popped up en masse in various border cities. For 10 points, name this 1994 agreement that allows Mexico to trade freely with the USA.

4. An 1898 short by George Albert Smith titled for this person was the first use of the double-exposure special effect in film. Peter the Knook joins this person at the end of a "Life and Adventures" by L. Frank Baum. This person's modern iconography comes from commercial illustrator Haddon Sundblom, who drew on the best-known work by General Theological Seminary professor (*) Clement Clarke Moore. An 1897 letter about this person addressed to The New York Sun earned lifelong fame for eight-year-old Virginia O'Hanlon. Allegedly, a misprint of a department store hotline led NORAD to begin "tracking" this person's location. For 10 points, name this person who gives presents to nice children on Christmas Eve.

5. Description acceptable. These regions are constrained by maladaptive gene flow in the genetic swamping hypothesis. Rapoport’s rule constrains these regions if they appear in extreme locations. These regions are subdivided by vicariance. In one model, a series of these regions forms a "ring" with incompatible ends. If one of these regions spans much of the Earth, then it is "cosmopolitan." The latitudes of these regions cause allometric variation according to (*) Allen's and Bergmann's rules. These regions are respectively extended, split, and maintained in peripatric, allopatric, and sympatric speciation. These regions are expanded by dispersal and migration. For 10 points, name these ecological regions in which a given species lives.
ANSWER: species ranges [accept species distributions or habitats or geographic ranges; accept answers describing a region where a given species lives before the end; prompt on ring species]

6. Description acceptable. Ceremonial procedures of these events are described in a 15th century Johannes Burchard text published 400 years later. Special coins featuring a parasol and two crossed keys were issued during these events. The secretary of these events traditionally receives a red zucchetto at their end. A three-year one of these events that ended in 1271 resulted in the proclamation of Ubi periculum. These events coincide with a period known as (*) sede vacante. The fumata bianca indicates a two-thirds majority has been reached, concluding these events. Participants in these events sleep in bunk beds under the painted ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. For 10 points, name these events where a new head of the Catholic Church is chosen.

A city on this body of water is the more northern claimant to a sandwich made of mojo pork and cheese invented by immigrants. The American Salvador Dalí Museum is in a city on this body of water connected to Terra Ceia by the Sunshine Skyway Bridge. The Big Bend Power Plant near this body of water's Apollo Beach releases warm water that attracts (*) manatees. Cigar factories in Ybor City along this body of water drew in Cuban immigrants. 9. The use of cyano·biphenyls as discotics in these materials was popularized by George Gray. Stephanie Kwolek's work with polymer solutions of these materials led to her discovery of Kevlar. In-plane switching improves the performance of devices that use these materials, which typically have an order parameter between 0.3 and 0.9. The "cholesteric" type of these materials form unaligned layers, unlike their (*) smectic type. An electric field polarizes these materials to make them transparent or opaque in the twisted nematic effect. These materials display properties of both fluids and ordered solids, and organic LEDs are replacing them in namesake displays. For 10 points, name these materials, the "LC" in LCD.
ANSWER: liquid crystals [or mesogens; accept liquid crystal displays; prompt on LCDs until "LC" is read; reject partial answers]

10. This author wrote "I'm going out to fetch the little calf" in two quatrains ending "I shan't be gone long - you come too." This poet wrote about an animal "not to blame for his key" in "A Minor Bird," and described "a dimpled spider, fat and white, holding up a moth" in "Design." In one work, this poet complains of hunters who "would have the rabbit out of hiding" and create (*) gaps in stones, before noting "But here there are no cows" to question whether "Good fences make good neighbors." This poet wrote "My little horse must think it queer / To stop without a farmhouse near" in a poem ending "And miles to go before I sleep." For 10 points, name this poet of "Mending Wall" and "Stopping By Woods on a Snowy Evening."
ANSWER: Robert Frost [or Robert Lee Frost] (The poem in the first line is "The Pasture.")
<Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Poetry> ~30067~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>

11. The Orchestre Révolutionnaire et Romantique ("or-KESS-truh ray-vo-loo-see-oh-NAIR ay ro-mahn-TEEK") performed this symphony in a 2003 BBC film dramatizing its first rehearsal. Its composer's opus 35 and this symphony's finale are sets of variations on a contredanse beginning "pickup E-flat, long G, short E-flat, long D." This symphony was written a year after its composer resolved not to kill himself in the Heiligenstadt ("HIGH-lih-gen-shtat") Testament. This symphony uses the relative C minor for its second movement (*) funeral march. The start of the Romantic era is often traced to the two forte E-flat major chords that open this symphony. The subtitle "composed to celebrate the memory of a great man" replaced a dedication to Napoleon in, for 10 points, what Beethoven symphony about heroism?
ANSWER: Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 in E-flat major [or the Eroica Symphony; or Sinfonia Eroica; accept Eroica - The Day That Changed Music Forever; accept the Heroic Symphony until "heroism"; prompt on Symphony No. 3 until "Beethoven" is read and accept thereafter] (The second clue refers to the Eroica Variations.)

12. This deity must wade through a boiling river to reach the well Urðarbrunnr ("ur-thur-BROO-nur") instead of crossing Bifrost. Shaking mountains alert the servant Beyla of this deity's arrival during a flyting. This deity kills a jötunn ("YO-tun") who is enraged by the horse Svaðilfari ("SVAH-thil-far-ee") chasing a god disguised as a mare. This deity smashes a chalice against the skull of (*) Hymir, a jötunn ("YO-tun") this deity goes fishing with, in a story that features the creature that kills this deity at Ragnarok. Utgard-Loki tricks this deity into drinking from the ocean and lifting Jörmungandr ("YOR-mun-gahn-dur"). This deity uses a set of iron gloves to wield a weapon whose accidentally shortened handle led it to be used with one hand. For 10 points, name this strong god who owns Mjölnir.
ANSWER: Thor [accept Thuner or Donar]

13. This period's rock formations include Old Red Sandstone and the Rhynie Chert, which names this period's vascular plant genus Rhynia. Phacopid trilobites went extinct at the end of this period in the Hangenberg event, which was smaller than the Kellwasser event that separates its Frasnian and Famennian ages. While it's mostly in the following period, Romer's gap in the fossil record began in this period. The crocodile-like transitional fossil Tiktaalik is from this period that contained the earliest appearances of (*) ammonites, four-legged amphibians, and forests. The Silurian and Carboniferous periods bookend this "Age of Fishes." For 10 points, a southwest England county names what period abbreviated "D"?
ANSWER: Devonian period [prompt on D until read; prompt on Age of Fishes until read]
<David Bass, Science - Other Science> ~31111~ <Editor: David Bass>

14. The first UN award named for this variable was co-won by Qian Xinzhong, chair of China's NFPC. This variable declines after the year 2030 according to the 1972 World3 computer simulation funded by the Club of Rome. A 1970 Tonight Show appearance sparked panic about this variable when Paul Ehrlich discussed his book on its (*) "bomb." A campaign to reduce this variable during The Emergency led by Sanjay Gupta forced many men to get surgeries. People who violated a policy begun in 1979 to decrease this variable were denied a hukou. 19th century fears that an increase in this variable led to poverty sparked the formation of the Malthusian League. For 10 points, name this variable reduced via China's One Child policy.
ANSWER: human population [accept descriptions such as size of the global population or the population of China or India; accept over-population; accept The Population Bomb; accept number of people in the world; prompt on family size or fertility rate or number of children or number of people by asking "what global variable does that contribute to?"]

15. In a play by this writer, a man declares that he does not "like the months of the year" after he is asked to imitate February. In a play by this writer, capital letters are used to write "ANGELFOOD" by the Orator after the Old Man and the Old Woman shout "Long live the Emperor" and jump out the window. 17. Accusations that the son of this city's king was poisoned by Joseph ibn Naghrela led to a 1066 pogrom. Zawi ibn Ziri sailed north to establish the Zirids in this city. A ruler of this city was told, "Weep like a woman for a kingdom you could not defend like a man." [10e] Keratinocytes of the epidermis receive this polymer from the stratum basale. This pigment drives the coloration of human skin.
ANSWER: melanin

12. A poem by this author addressed "to my Lord Fairfax" asks, "Why should of all things man unrul'd / Such unproportioned dwellings build?" For 10 points each:
[10m] Name this author of the country house poem "Upon Appleton House." This author's most famous poem ends, "though we cannot make our sun / Stand still, yet we will make him run."
ANSWER: Andrew Marvell (The poem is "To His Coy Mistress.")
[10h] A character in this novella takes his nickname "Starry" from "Upon Appleton House." This novella ends with a poem named for its title character "in the Darbies" ending "the oozy weeds about me twist."
ANSWER: Billy Budd, Sailor (An Inside Narrative) [or Billy Budd, Foretopman; prompt on "Billy in the Darbies" by asking "what novella is that poem from?"]
[10e] Billy Budd was written by this author, who created a hymn describing "The ribs and terrors in the whale" in his novel Moby Dick.
ANSWER: Herman Melville

13. This man's ranch was foreclosed upon by Edward Doheny in the aftermath of a criminal case in which Doheny himself was acquitted. For 10 points each:
[10h] Name this man who became the first Cabinet minister to go to prison following a case in which Harry Sinclair was convicted of contempt of court after a mistrial.
ANSWER: Albert Bacon Fall
[10m] Fall was imprisoned for his role in this event, in which he was bribed to illegally lease the US Navy's oil reserves to private companies.
ANSWER: Teapot Dome scandal
[10e] The Teapot Dome scandal retrospectively tarnished the Presidency of this Republican, whose sudden death in 1923 led to his replacement by Calvin Coolidge.
ANSWER: Warren G. Harding [or Warren Gamaliel Harding]

14. In Race Matters, Cornel West called the adoption of this philosophical view "the major enemy of Black survival in America." For 10 points each:
[10e] Name this philosophical view often summarized as "nothing matters."
ANSWER: nihilism [accept word forms like nihilist]
[10h] According to Keiji Nishitani, nihilism is a Western notion derived from a form of negativity that he contrasted with this Sanskrit term. This term, central to Buddhist philosophy, is often translated as "emptiness."
ANSWER: śūnyatā ("shoon-yuh-tah")
[10m] Nishitani defined Western "nihility" in a book titled for this practice and Nothingness. William James contrasted healthy-minded and sick-souled approaches to this practice in a book on the varieties of its experience.
ANSWER: religion [accept religious experiences or mystical experiences; accept Religion and Nothingness; accept The Varieties of Religious Experience]
<Sean Farrell, RMP - Philosophy> ~24703~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

15. Although these apps are banned in China, many of the most popular ones come from that country. For 10 points each:
[10e] Identify these programs, which include TunnelBear. YouTube ads often tout how these programs trick Netflix into thinking you're logging in from another country.
ANSWER: VPNs [or virtual private networks]
[10m] This security company purchased TunnelBear in 2018. This company's founder and namesake hanged himself in a Barcelona prison in 2021 after learning he would be extradited to the US to face tax evasion charges.
ANSWER: McAfee Corp. [accept John McAfee]
[10h] This senator has called for an investigation into the use of VPNs as spying tools. This Oregon Democrat and privacy advocate introduced the 2019 Mind Your Own Business Act.
ANSWER: Ron Wyden [or Ronald Lee Wyden]

19. A bracketed alpha denotes a form of rotation named for this adjective that is equal and opposite for L and D-isomers. For 10 points each:
[10h] Give this adjective that describes reactions where the stereochemistry of the reactants entirely determines the stereochemistry of the products.
ANSWER: specific [accept stereospecific; accept specific rotation]
[10m] Stereospecific reactions can either produce dia•stereomers or these isomers. Specific rotation can be used to measure ratios of these isomers, which are respectively denoted "R" and "S."
ANSWER: enantiomers [accept enantiomeric excess]
[10e] Stereospecific reactions may also form achiral meso isomers, which have at least this many chiral centers. Ethanol and ethane both have this number of carbon atoms.
ANSWER: two

20. The Gayatri ("GUY-uh-tree") mantra is dedicated to Savitr ("SAH-vee-tur"), a member of the Adityas, who govern this domain. For 10 points each:
[10e] Name this celestial domain governed by Surya, who is venerated by flying kites during Makar Sankranti.
ANSWER: the Sun
[10h] Kites are also flown during this festival, observed on the last day of Shravana. It's not Bhai Dooj, but during this festival, sisters tie a piece of string around their brothers' wrists as a symbol of protection.
ANSWER: Raksha Bandhan [or Rakhi; or Saluno; or Silono; or Rakri]
[10m] The kite fighting game of changa chait is played during this country's festivals of Dashain and Tihar. Hindus often pilgrim to the Pashupatinath ("PUH-shoo-PUH-tin-aath") temple in this modern-day country, where Queen Maya gave birth to the Buddha.
ANSWER: Nepal [or Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal]

21. Description required. The town of Lepakshi is attributed to be a place where Jatayu fell trying to stop this event. For 10 points each:
[10m] Describe this event, facilitated by a rakshasa who lures his target outside of Lakhsmana's protective boundary.
ANSWER: abduction of Sita [accept synonyms for abduction like kidnapping]
[10e] Jatayu had tried in vain to save Sita from this ten-headed rakshasa, the primary antagonist of the Ramayana.
ANSWER: Ravana [accept Ravana Dashagriva or Ravanasura or Ravanaeshwaran or Dasis Sakvithi Maha Ravana; accept Lankapati or Lankeshwar or Lankeshwaran; accept Dashaanan]
[10h] Jatayu and his brother Sampati are both depicted as these creatures. They are nephews of another of these creatures who forced Kaliya to leave Ramanaka Dwipa.
ANSWER: birds [accept vultures; accept eagles] (Lepakshi, mentioned in the lead-in, translates to "get up, bird.")
